div.p: A DISCOURSE ON THE Tranſcendent Glory OF THE GOSPEL. Deliver'd at the Lecture in Hingham.
By Ebenezer Gay, M. A. Paſtor of a CHURCH there.

q.p: The Glory of this latter Houſe ſhall be greater than of the former, ſaith the Lord of hoſts.

Even the myſtery which hath been hid from Ages, and from Generations, but now is made manifeſt to his Saints, to whom God would make known what is the Riches of the Glory of this myſtery among the Gentiles, which is Chriſt in you, the Hope of Glory.

div.p: BOSTON in New-England: Printed for D. HENCHMAN, over againſt the Brick Meeting-Houſe in Cornhil. MDCCXXVIII.

div.head: To the People of my Charge.

opener.salute: Dearly Beloved in our Lord Jeſus Chriſt,

div.p:
IT was very pleaſing unto me, to obſerve ſo general a Deſire amongſt you, that a Monthly-Lecture might be preached in this Town: I was glad when ye ſaid unto me, let us go into the houſe of the Lord. And your Attendence of ſuch a religious Exerciſe, hath been hitherto uncommon and exemplary. I hope that you find Godlineſs to be profitable for all things, having the promiſe of the life that now is, and of that which is to come. It is at the Requeſt of many of you, and with an aim at the Good of all your Souls, that theſe Diſcourſes are made ſo public. I am very ſenſible, that they are far below the dignity of the Subjects treated of; and if they ſhou'd (as moſt probably they will in this critical Age) be cenſured as weak and mean, I ſhall not blame any for being of my Opinion: But I truſt that you, to whom theſe Sermons were acceptable when preached, will read them with Candor, and a ſuitable concern that ye may be edified thereby. I ſend them abroad in a plain Country-Dreſs, it being ſuch as I could afford them, and which will be moſt agreable to thoſe on whom I depend to give them Entertainment. You receive them from the Preſs, in the ſame words that you had them from the Pulpit. — The ſeaſonableneſs of theſe Diſcourſes, cannot (I think) be juſtly excepted againſt. The Contempt of the glorious Goſpel is doubtleſs the moſt provoking Evil of the Times, and is comprehenſive of all thoſe Sins, for which the righteous GOD hath a Controverſy with our Land: An Eſſay therefore to raiſe in us due Tho'ts of the Excellency of the Goſpel, will not be judged needleſs. While we are contemplating & adoring the Glory of GOD, which he hath diſcover'd in his late remarkable & amazing works of Providence, we ſhou'd not over-look, nor be unaffected with that brighter Diſplay of it, which there is in the Goſpel. GOD's ſaving manifeſtation of himſelf, is not to be expected in his providential
Diſpenſations, ordinary or extraordinary, nor in the Terrors of the Law, but in the Glaſs of his Goſpel. The Lord was not in the wind, nor in the earthquake, nor in the fire, but in the ſtill ſmall voice, 1 Kin. 19.11, 12.

THE Voice of GOD, which is full of majeſty, from the deep places of the Earth, hath awaken'd many to give the more earneſt Heed to his ſweet & gracious Voice, ſpeaking from Heaven in the Goſpel of CHRIST; and by the latter more than the former, is their Converſion (which we hope is real) effected. There are many excellent Sermons lately publiſh'd, to teach & excite us rightly to conſider & improve the terrible Works of GOD: and a Diſcourſe concerning the Glory of the Goſpel, may alſo, by the divine Bleſſing, ſerve to promote the Reformation, which is ſo earneſtly prayed & labour'd for.—Altho', to our ſhame & ſorrow it muſt be ſaid, there hath not been that noiſe & ſhaking among the dry bones here, which there hath been in other places under the late awful Diſpenſations, yet ſome (I hope) have been awakened to flee from wrath: and that they might continue to run well, and not look back, I have put them in remembrance of Lot's Wife.
THESE Sermons I dedicate unto you, my beloved People, and wiſh they might be profitable to your Souls, for which I will very gladly ſpend, and be ſpent.

I rejoyce in the Lord, that your Care of me hath flouriſhed, in the proviſion ye have made for my outward Support, ever ſince I have been in the work of the Miniſtry amongſt you. And I ſpeak it to your praiſe, that I have not been neceſſitated to ask for any maintenance; but what ye have done towards it, ye have done of your own accord, as ſenſible that a Miniſter is not to live on the Alms of his People, but that the Labourer is worthy of his Hire. —There is one thing I need, and do now ask of you, to wit, Your more fervent Prayers unto GOD for me, that he would make me an able and faithful Miniſter of the New Teſtament; and that after I have preached to you in Chriſt's Name, I may not (as there is great danger that I ſhall) periſh eternally in his wrath. — Brethren pray for me, that the Word of the Lord may have free Courſe amongſt us, and be glorified.

div.head: THE Tranſcendent Glory OF THE GOSPEL Diſplayed.

q.p: FOR even that which was made Glorious, had no Glory in this reſpect, by reaſon of the Glory that excelleth.

div.p:
THE Sovereignty and Power of divine Grace were marvellouſly diſplay'd in the Converſion of Paul, who before was a furious Perſecutor of the Church of Chriſt. And the Grace of God which was beſtowed on him, was not in vain; for He laboured more abundantly than all his Fellow-workers unto the Kingdom. And GOD highly honoured Him, in propagating & promoting Chriſtianity in the World, more by his Miniſtry than any other Man's. The ſhining Gifts & extraordinary Succeſs of this great Apoſtle, drew upon him the envious Hatred of falſe Teachers; who maliciouſly endeavour'd to blaſt his Reputation, and obſtruct his Uſefulneſs. This oblig'd him to ſpeak much in his own vindication: which He did,
not out of Arrogance and Oſtentation, but a ſincere reſpect to the Glory of GOD, and the Good of the Church. Do we begin again (ſaith he in the firſt verſe of this Chapter) to commend our ſelves? or need we as ſome others, Epiſtles of commendation to you, or Letters of commendation from you. The Apoſtle ſpeaks in the plural Number, becauſe He wrote not only in his own, but alſo in Timothy's Name to the Corinthians. He had begun again in the preceding Chapter to commend himſelf, by declaring his faithfulneſs, as he had done in his firſt Epiſtle to them. But here he ſeems to Check himſelf for it; and tells them, that he needed, not as others (meaning falſe Apoſtles & Teachers) commendatory Letters to them or from them: For they themſelves, in regard of the Succeſs of his Miniſtry amongſt them, were a living Epiſtle, that might ſufficiently recommend him to them, and to all other Churches. Ye are our Epiſtle written in our hearts, known and read of all men. As if he had ſaid, You that have been Converted by my preaching, are a commendatory Epiſtle, which I carry about in my heart, having always a thankful and dear Remembrance of you, and which may ſatisfy all that have heard of your Faith and Obedience, that I am a true Apoſtle and faithful Miniſter of JESUS CHRIST. And he thus ſtrongly proves that they were ſuch an Epiſtle. Foraſmuch as ye are manifeſtly declared to be the Epiſtle of Chriſt miniſtred by us, written not with Ink, but with the Spirit of the living GOD, not in Tables of ſtone, but in fleſhly Tables of the heart. Their holy Converſation declar'd them to be the Epiſtle of CHRIST. By them CHRIST ſignified his Mind and Will to others, as a Man doth his by a Letter. They were a living Rule, ſhewing by their Actions how all ought to walk. JESUS CHRIST with his Spirit, that accompanied the Apoſtle's Miniſtry, did make ſaving Impreſſions on their Hearts; wrote his Law, not on Tables of Stone, but fleſhly Tables, the Hearts of Believers. And ſuch Truſt have we through Chriſt to God-ward. The Apoſtle was humbly confident, that GOD had thus bleſſed
his Miniſtry to them. Not that we are ſufficient of our ſelves to think any thing as of our ſelves: but our ſufficiency is of God. Paul acknowledgeth that He was ſo far from being the Author of the good Work in the Corinthian Chriſtians, that He could not of himſelf ſo much as think. A Man cannot think any thing without the Influence of divine Providence, and he cannot think a good Thought without the Influence of divine Grace. Every Act is from GOD, as he is the GOD of Nature, and the Goodneſs of any Act is from Him, as He is the GOD of all Grace. The Apoſtle was very careful not to exalt himſelf, when he was magnifying his Office. Our ſufficiency (ſaith he) is of GOD: who alſo hath made us able Miniſters of the New Teſtament. i. e. The Goſpel, called a Teſtament, becauſe it is a free & firm Diſpoſition of the Mediator's good things unto the Heirs of Salvation, to be poſſeſſed by them according to his Will; and the New Teſtament, in regard of the ancient Promiſes of thoſe good things under the Law. The Apoſtle having thus aſcribed unto GOD, the Praiſe of all his Ability for and Succeſs in the Work of the Miniſtry, He proves the Dignity of his Office by drawing a Compariſon between the Law and the Goſpel, and ſhewing how the latter did exceed the former in Glory. By ſeveral Arguments he demonſtrates the ſurpaſſing Excellency of the Goſpel; and in our Text declares that the Law, altho' glorious in it ſelf, and the manner of it's delivery, yet compar'd with the Goſpel, hath no Glory at all: like as the Glory of the Stars diſappears at the riſing of the Sun. For even that which was made glorious, had no glory in this reſpect, by reaſon of the glory that excelleth.
THE DOCTRINE from the Words is this, viz.

div.head: DOCTRINE, THAT the Goſpel is incomparably more glorious than the Law.
div.p: BY the Law, we may underſtand the Revelation which GOD made of himſelf, his Mind & Will before the coming of CHRIST in the fleſh; and by the Goſpel, the Revelation which GOD hath granted ſince that Time: The former is contain'd in the Scriptures uſually ſtiled the Old Teſtament, the latter in thoſe of the New. By the Law is ſometimes meant the Decalogue only, or ten Commandments, called the moral Law; ſometimes the Ceremonial Inſtitutions, the Law of Commandments contained in Ordinances; ſometimes all the Scriptures of the Old Teſtament, the Writings of Moſes and the Prophets. The Law, taken in either of theſe Senſes, hath comparatively no Glory, in reſpect of the Glory of the Goſpel that excelleth. The Law is in our Context, ſaid to be glorious, and the Goſpel is ſtiled the glorious Goſpel, 2 Cor. 4.4. The Law is in the verſe preceding our Text, called Glory it ſelf and the Goſpel is ſo termed, 1 Theſ. 2.12. But altho' the Law be very excellent and glorious, yet the Goſpel far exceedeth it in Glory. Compar'd with the Glory of the Goſpel, the Law hath none.
WHEREIN, and how far the Goſpel exceeds the Law in Glory, is now to be conſider'd by us.
I. THE Goſpel is more Glorious than the Law, in regard of the firſt Publiſher of it.

THE Law is, in our Text, ſaid to be that, which was made Glorious: Beſides it's intrinſick Glory, there was ſome additional Glory made to it, by GOD'S ſending of it to his People, by the hand of ſo excellent a Perſon, as He did: But the Glory which the Goſpel hath in reſpect of the tranſcendent Dignity of the Lord's Meſſenger, who firſt publiſhed it, far exceedeth that. The Law was given by Moſes, but Grace and Truth (i. e. the Goſpel, called Grace in oppoſition to the Severity of the Law, and Truth in oppoſition to the Types and Shadows of the legal Diſpenſation) came by Jeſus Chriſt, Joh. 1.17. Moſes, whom GOD employed to deliver the Law to his ancient People, was a glorious Saint and extraordinary
Prophet: but the Lord Jeſus Chriſt, by whom the Goſpel at firſt began to be ſpoken, did infinitely excel Him. The Meſſiah was promiſed of old, as a Prophet like unto Moſes, Deut. 18.15. He did in many reſpects ſignally reſemble Moſes: but this don't imply that he was not in all ſuperior to him. CHRIST was not only like to Moſes in Moſes's chiefeſt Excellencies, but He alſo infinitely ſurpaſſed him. Heb. 3.3. This Man was counted worthy of more glory than Moſes. Moſes was but a Man, Chriſt was GOD as well as Man: Moſes was not without Sin, but Chriſt was holy, harmleſs, undefiled, ſeparate from Sinners: Moſes was only a Servant, Chriſt was alſo the Son of GOD. When Moſes came down from Mount Sinai, bringing the two Tables of Teſtimony, his Face ſhone with a dazling Glory, Exod. 34.30. When Aaron and all the Children of Iſrael ſaw Moſes, behold, the skin of his Face ſhone, and they were afraid to come nigh him. This is mention'd in our Context, v. 7. as one thing which made the Law glorious; The miniſtration of Death written and ingraven in ſtones, was glorious, ſo that the Children of Iſrael could not ſtedfaſtly behold the Face of Moſes, for the Glory of his Countenance. The Luſtre ſpread on the Face of Moſes, was an evidence to the Jews, of the GOD of Glory's ſending him to publiſh the Law unto them. But Jeſus Chriſt far excel'd Moſes in the viſible Glory wherewith his Face did ſhine, when GOD, by a voice from Heaven, declar'd him to be his Son, by whom he would ſpeak, and unto whom Men ſhou'd hearken. Moſes in all his Glory, was not arrayed with ſuch Splendor as Chriſt was, at his ſolemn Inveſtiture into his Office. When Jeſus was baptized, Heaven was opened to pour down it's Glory on him: and the holy Ghoſt deſcended in a bodily ſhape, like a Dove upon him, Luk. 3.21, 22. The holy Ghoſt is incorporeal, but he then aſſumed a bodily viſible Shape, and doubtleſs one that was very bright and glorious. Some think, that it cannot be concluded from what the Scripture ſaith concerning the holy Ghoſt's Deſcent on Chriſt, that he appeared in the form of a Dove:
But ſuppoſe that he aſſum'd a Body of Light, or Fire, and therein came down, in ſuch like manner as a Dove, with it's Wings ſpread forth, and gathering about our SAVIOUR'S Head cover'd and crown'd it with a viſibly Glory. But why may we not, according to the Letter of the Scripture, conceive that the bodily Shape in which the holy Ghoſt deſcended on Chriſt, was that of a Dove, intimating the Dove-like Diſpoſition of the harmleſs JESUS? And yet, we have reaſon to believe that it was in ſome luminous form, ſome extraordinary appearance of Light, that the holy Ghoſt came down on our Saviour. Juſtin Martyr ſpeaking of Chriſt's Baptiſm ſaith, that there was a Fire lighted in the River Jordan. "By which it appears, that it was an early Tradition in the Church, that the Water, immediately after Chriſt was baptized in it, ſeem'd to be all on Fire by the Reflection of that bright and flaming appearance, in which the holy Ghoſt deſcended upon him". And at his Tranſfiguration on Mount Tabor, His Face did ſhine as the Sun, and his Raiment was white as the Light, Mat. 27.2. His Face did ſhine as the Sun in it's meridian Brightneſs, and his Raiment was like the whitneſs of a flaſh of Lightning. The three Diſciples that were with Chriſt on the Mount, were afraid and aſtoniſhed at the ſight, as Aaron and the Iſraelites were at the ſight of the Glory on Moſes's Face. The Honour and Glory which Chriſt received from GOD the Father, at his Baptiſm and Transfiguration, was too great to be communicated to any but the Son of GOD; It was therefore the Sign, by which John the Baptiſt knew him to be the true Meſſiah; and upon which he grounded his Teſtimony concerning him, Joh. 1.33, 34. I know him not: but he that ſent me to baptize with water; the ſame ſaid unto me, upon whom thou ſhalt ſee he Spirit deſcending and remaining on him, the ſame 〈…〉 which baptizeth with the holy Ghoſt. And I ſa • & 〈◊〉 record that this is the Son of God. The viſible Splendor with which Chriſt was inveſted at his Baptiſm and Transfiguration, was ſo great, that all who beheld it might rationally conclude that he was
the Son of GOD: Such Glory wou'd not be imparted to any other. John the Evangeliſt, who was an Eyewitneſs of the Glory ſhed on Chriſt at his Transfiguration, and probably of that at his Baptiſm alſo, doth partly with reference thereunto ſay, Joh. 1.14. We beheld his glory, the glory as of the only begotten of the Father. The Glory was ſuch as became him, who was the only begotten Son of GOD: It was queſtionleſs therefore a Glory far ſurpaſſing that on the Face of Moſes, when he brought down the Law from Sinai. Jeſus Chriſt muſt be infinitely more glorious than Moſes, being the Brightneſs of God's glory, and the expreſs Image of his Perſon, Heb. 1.3. In him dwelt all the fulneſs of the infinite Godhead bodily, and from him did it ſhine forth in the Days of his Fleſh, he being the Effulgence of his Father's Glory. Moſes was not more than a Prophet, John the Baptiſt was, and among them that are born of Women, there aroſe not a greater than John; yet he counted himſelf not worthy to do the meanneſt Office for CHRIST, to be the leaſt and loweſt of his Attendants, Luke 3.16. —One mightier than I cometh, the latchet of whoſe Shoes I am not worthy to unlooſe.
THUS, in reſpect of the Glory which the Law and Goſpel receive from the ſhining Excellencies of the firſt Publiſhers thereof, the latter doth abundantly exceed the former in Glory.
II. THE Goſpel is more glorious than the Law in regard of the Circumſtances which attended the Promulgation of it.

THE Law was made glorious by the manner of it's delivery. When the LORD came down on Mount Sinai, holy Angels were the Chariots of his Glory, He rode upon Cherubims, and there was an illuſtrious Appearance of Myriads of them, Pſal. 68.17. The Chariots of God are twenty thouſand, even thouſands of Angels: the Lord is among them as in Sinai, in the holy place. The Mount was altogether on a ſmoke, becauſe the LORD deſcended upon it in Fire: and the ſmoke thereof aſcended as the ſmoke of a Furnace,
and the whole Mount quaked greatly: Sinai was moved at the Preſence of the GOD of Iſrael. There was the ſound of a Trumpet, long and loud; the noiſe of Thunders, and the voice of Words, very terrifying. The glorious manner in which GOD gave the Law on Sinai, is elegantly ſet forth by the Prophet, Hab. 3.3, 4. GOD came from Teman, and the holy One from Mount Paran, Selah. His Glory covered the Heavens, and the Earth was full of his Praiſe, or Splendor. And his brightneſs was as the light, he had horns, or bright Beams, coming out of his hand: "Rays of Glory were darted forth around Him" With ſuch Tokens of Majeſty was the Promulgation of the Law attended. But, altho' there was leſs Terror, yet there was not leſs Glory in the Circumſtances which accompanied the firſt Publication of the Goſpel. It was uſher'd in, by Angel's declaring and celebrating the Birth of JESUS, that Horn of Salvation which GOD promis'd to raiſe up unto his People, in the Houſe of his Servant David. The poor Shepherds at Bethlehem, ſaw as great Glory there, and as bright an Apparition of Angels, as the Iſraelites did at Sinai, and heard more glorious Words, Luke 2.9, 10, 11. Lo, the Angel of the Lord came upon them, and the glory of the Lord ſhone round about them; and they were ſore afraid. And the Angel ſaid unto them, fear not, for behold, I bring you good tydings of great Joy, which ſhall be to all people, for unto you is born this day in the city of David, a Saviour; which is Chriſt the Lord. ver. 13, 14. And ſuddenly there was with the Angel, a multitude of the heavenly hoſt, praiſing God, and ſaying, Glory to God in the higheſt, and on Earth peace, good will towards Men. — A glorious Lamp was lighted in the aetherial Heaven, an extraordinary Star appeared, to give notice to the World of the Approach of the Sun of Righteouſneſs, Matth. 2.1, 2. Now when Jeſus was born in Bethlehem of Judea, in the days of Herod the king: behold, there came wiſe men from the Eaſt to Jeruſalem, ſaying, where is He that is born king of the Jews? for we have ſeen his Star in the Eaſt, and are come to worſhip
him. — Was there not more Glory deriv'd on the Goſpel, from what was done and ſaid at Chriſt's Baptiſm and Transfiguration, than there was on the Law, from all that Majeſty and awful Pomp that Mount Sinai was cover'd with? What a glorious Scene was it, for Heaven to open, and the holy Ghoſt viſibly to deſcend on Chriſt to array Him with a dazling Splendor, and ſuch a voice to come from the excellent Glory, This is my beloved Son, in whom I am well pleaſed, hear ye Him? Was there any Brightneſs at Sinai, comparable to that on Mount Tabor? or any Voice ſo glorious? — And in order to the more full and extenſive Publication of the Goſpel, by the Apoſtles of Chriſt, the Deſcent of the holy Ghoſt upon them, at the Feaſt of Pentecoſt (the ſame time of the Year, that the Law was given at Sinai) was a thing which equal'd, if not exceeded in glory, any Circumſtance which attended the Promulgation of the Law. There was indeed no Trumpet, nor terrifying Voice, no Thunder, Darkneſs nor Tempeſt, but a ſound from Heaven, as of a ruſhing mighty Wind, and it filled all the Houſe where the Apoſtles were ſitting; and there was the Appearance of bright flames of Fire, cleaving aſunder; and in the form of Tongues reſting on the Heads of the Diſciples, and they ſpake all Languages to the aſtoniſhment of multitudes who were then preſent, Act. 2. So that the publication of the Goſpel was graced with as remarkable and glorious Circumſtances, as that of the Law. It might alſo, under this Head, be ſhown, How the Miracles which attended the publication of the Goſpel, thro' Chriſt's and his Apoſtle's time on Earth, did, both in number and greatneſs, far exceed thoſe which accompanied the Promulgation of the Law. Moſes and the Prophets did not, all of them do, ſo many, nor ſuch mighty Works, as JESUS of Nazareth did. How great muſt that Salvation be, how glorious that Goſpel, which at firſt began to be ſpoken, and was thus proved by the Lord, and was afterwards confirmed likewiſe by them that heard him; GOD bearing them witneſs, both with Signs and Wonders,
and with diverſe Miracles, and gifts of the holy Ghoſt, according to his will?
III. THE Goſpel is more glorious than the Law, in reſpect of its revealing the Glory of GOD ſo much more clearly and fully, than the Law doth.
Particularly,
1. THE Glory of divine Mercy ſhining in the Face of Jeſus Chriſt, it clearly diſplayed by the Goſpel.

GOD'S Goodneſs is his Glory; and this is moſt clearly and fully revealed in the Goſpel; the ſum of which is, that God is in Chriſt, reconciling the World unto himſelf, not imputing their Treſpaſſes unto them. The moral Law diſcovers nothing of GOD'S Mercy toward ſinful Creatures: and the ceremonial Law had only a ſhadow of good things to come, and not the very Image of the things: It contain'd a dark and imperfect, not a lively and full Repreſentation of thoſe good things, which the Mercy of GOD deſigned for miſerable Sinners. The Myſtery of Chriſt, which the Goſpel reveals, was under the legal Diſpenſation wrapped up in Types, Ceremonies, and obſcure Propheſies and Promiſes. The Goſpel, the Preaching of Jeſus Chriſt is the revelation of the myſtery, which was kept ſecret ſince the world began, Rom. 16.25. The Riches of Grace, the unſearchable Riches of Chriſt were, in a great meaſure hid, before the Goſpel open'd them; ſo that as the Prophet, and after him, the Apoſtle ſaid concerning the ſame, Eye had not ſeen, nor Ear heard, neither had entred into the Heart of Man, the things which God hath prepared for them that Love him.
2. THE Glory of divine Wiſdom, ſhining in the face of Jeſus Chriſt is eminently diſplayed in the Goſpel.

WHEN the Bowels of GOD'S Mercy were troubled for us, the Mouth of his Juſtice was opened againſt us miſerable Sinners. Juſtice demanded the everlaſting
Deſtruction of Guilty, and therefore defervedly accurſed Creatures; and back'd it's Demand with powerful Arguments, taken from the Holineſs of GOD, and his Veracity in his Threatnings: And Mercy's Pleas for the Salvation of the miſerable Children of Men, were ſo importunate, that GOD would not reject them. Therefore he employ'd his infinite Wiſdom in the Counſel of Peace between the Father and the Son, to contrive a Method of Redemption, in which theſe Attributes ſhou'd harmonize, Juſtice and Mercy kiſs each other, and be glorified together. And this adorable Wiſdom the Goſpel reveals; Wiſdom, which was before hidden, 1 Cor. 2.7. Wiſdom, which the bleſſed Angels diſcover'd nothing of by their immediate Views of the divine Glory in Heaven; They always behold the Face of GOD, yet they ſaw not this Wiſdom till the Goſpel exhibited the Face of Jeſus Chriſt. Eph. 3.10. To the intent that now unto the Principalities & Powers in heavenly places, might be known by the church the manifold Wiſdom of God.

THUS the Glory of GOD, eſpecially the Glory of his Mercy & Wiſdom is moſt clearly diſcover'd in the Goſpel, Joh. 1.18. No man hath ſeen God at any time; the only begotten Son which is in the boſom of the Father; he hath declared him. The Boſom is the Seat of Love, and Repoſitory of Secrets: Jeſus Chriſt who is in the boſom of God the Father, hath by the Goſpel made known his tender Compaſſions and myſterious Counſels. The Goſpel being ſuch a Revelation, the Glory of it far ſurpaſſeth that of the Law
IV. THE Goſpel exceeds the Law in glory, inaſmuch as it is a general Revelation, deſigned for the uſe and benefit of mankind.

AS it is a clearer and more compleat Revelation of GOD, his Mind and Will, ſo it is intended and granted for the Inſtruction and Advantage of more than the Law was. The Law was a Revelation directed to the Jews peculiarly, and not vouchſafed to other
Nations, Pſal. 147.19, 20. He ſheweth his word unto Jacob, his ſtatutes and his Judgments unto Iſrael. He hath not dealt ſo with any Nation: and as for his Judgments, they have not known them. The Legal Deſpenſation was reſtrained to that People, whom the LORD Choſe to be a ſpecial People unto himſelf, above all that were upon the face of the Earth. To the Iſraelites pertained the Adoption, and the Glory, and the Covenants, and the giving of the Law, and the ſervice of GOD, and the 'Promiſes, Rom. 9.4. The Law of Commandments contained in Ordinances was a Wall of Partition, that fenced the Jewiſh Nation, and ſever'd, them from others, making them GOD'S Sacred Incloſure, into which the Gentiles ſhould not come, to partake of the Privileges of the Church. The Ceremonial Law is ſtiled the Enmity, being the cauſe and ſign of Enmity between Jews and Gentiles, keeping them at a diſtance from one another. Thus the Law was confined within narrow Bounds; was directed and reſtrained to the Uſe of one Nation, and that the feweſt of all People. But the Goſpel is a Diſpenſation, in it's Nature, and in it's Author's Deſign, general: or ſuch as reſpects Mankind, without any diſtinction of Nation. There is no Monopoly of it's Privileges. It is proportion'd to the need, and ordain'd for the benefit of Men of all Nations and Conditions. The Goſpel is (as the angelical Preacher ſaid) Good tydings of great Joy, which ſhall be to all people, Luke 2.10. The Grace of God, i.e. The Goſpel that bringeth Salvation, hath appeared to all Men, Tit. 2.11. Chriſt hath broken down the middle wall of partition between Jews and Gentiles; Having aboliſhed in his fleſh the enmity, even the Law of Commandments contained in Ordinances: and came and preached Peace, i. e. The Goſpel of Peace, to them which were afar off, and to them that were nigh. The Gentiles therefore are no more Strangers and Foreigners, but fellow Citizens with the Saints and of the houſhold of God, Eph. 2. Now a general Revelation intended and granted for the benefit of all, is more glorious than that which was particular, or reſtrained to one People.
That Glory excelleth, which is not only in it ſelf brighter, but alſo in it's extent ſpread further, than another Glory; and ſuch is the Glory of the Goſpel, compar'd with that of the Law. The Law was as a Lamp which illuminates one Room: The Goſpel is as the Sun, whoſe going forth is from one end of the Heaven, and his circuit unto the ends of it, diffuſing a univerſal Light. And ſurely the glory of the Sun, in this reſpect, far ſurpaſſeth that of a burning Lamp, and as much doth the Glory of the Goſpel that of the Law.
V. THE Goſpel is more glorious than the Law, becauſe it is the miniſtration of the Spirit.

THE Goſpel is in oppoſition to the Law, called the Spirit, and the miniſtration of the Spirit, Context, ver. 6.8. Becauſe the Spirit of GOD accompanies the Diſpenſation of it, much more than it did that of the Law. By means of the Goſpel Perſons receive the holy Spirit; Gal. 3.2. This only would I learn of you, received ye the Spirit by the works of the Law, or by the hearing of Faith? By the works of the Law, we are here to underſtand the doctrine of Juſtification by the Works of the Law, which the Judazing Teachers preached: and by the hearing of Faith, is meant the Doctrine of the Goſpel; hearing being put for the thing heard, and Faith for the Doctrine believed: By the hearing of Faith, and not by the Works of the Law is the Spirit received. It is true, that under the Law GOD beſtowed his Spirit on his Servants, Neh. 9.20. Thou gaveſt alſo thy good Spirit, to inſtruct them. But the holy Spirit is more plentifully granted under the Evangelical, than it was under the Legal Diſpenſation. The gift of the Spirit, in the largeſt meaſures of it, was reſerv'd for the Glory of Goſpel-times. GOD often promiſed, that in the Day of Goſpel-light he wou'd pour out his Spirit: This Phraſe imports his beſtowing of it plentifully. It is with an eye to Goſpel-times, that GOD'S giving his Spirit is expreſs'd by his pouring of it forth. The Spirit was more ſparingly given under the Law, than it is under the Goſpel; It then came
down from Heaven, at it were, in a few drops, but now, as it were, in a full Stream. Under the Goſpel, that Promiſe, I will pour out my Spirit on all Fleſh, is fulfill'd, Acts 2.16, 17. "There were ſome ſprinklings of it under the law, and confin'd to a ſeparate Nation, but now ſhowers are poured down upon all Nations, to make them fruitful in good Works". On this account the Goſpel is far more glorious than the Law, as the Apoſtle argueth in our Context, Ver. 7, 8. If the miniſtration of death (i. e. the Law) written and ingraven in ſtones was glorious — How ſhall not the miniſtration of the Spirit be rather glorious?
VI. THE Goſpel is far more glorious than the Law, in regard of the wonderful Effects produced by it.

THE glorious Things which have been, and ſtill are effected by the Goſpel, accompanied with the Spirit of GOD, declare it's ſurpaſſing Glory.— I might here Inſtance in thoſe great and marvellous things which were done by it in the World at the firſt Preaching thereof, and in thoſe alſo which it ſtill performeth in the Souls of Men; equal to which, in number, or Glory, were never accompliſhed by the Law.
1. THE Effects produced by the Goſpel in the World, at the firſt Preaching of it, were admirable and glorious.

THE Blow that was given to Satan's viſible Kingdom on Earth, by no other Weapon than the Goſpel, ſheweth the Excellency of it; and may well make us to ſay concerning it, as David of the Sword with which he ſlew Goliah, There is none like it. The Rulers of the darkneſs of this World never had a more extenſive Dominion, nor exercis'd a more Tyranical Power over the miſerable Children of Men, than about the time that the Goſpel began to be preached. The Devil was then ſeated and ſtrengthned in the Government of the Nations; was worſhipped as a God: He almoſt every where had his
Temples, Altars and Oracles, that were much frequented and conſulted. The People brought their Offerings unto him; he did eat the fat of Sacrifices, and drink the blood of drink-Offerings; yea the Blood of his cruel Votaries Sons & Daughters, whom they barbarouſly ſacrificed unto him. Idolatry & Superſtition every where prevailed. But by the Preaching of the Goſpel, the Devil's Kingdom was ſhaken, and he loſt that great Power which he before had in the World. Luke 10.17, 18. The ſeventy returned again with joy, ſaying, Lord, even the Devils are ſubject unto us, thro' thy name. And he ſaid unto them, I beheld Satan as Lightning fall from Heaven. Our Saviour in this Expreſſion, might allude unto Satan's firſt Fall from Heaven; when of an Angel of Light he became a Spirit of Darkneſs, and was in a moment caſt down from his glorious Seat in Heaven: So by the Preaching of the Goſpel he ſhou'd be turned out of the Throne which he had uſurped on Earth, and fall from his great Power in the World, as Lightning flaſheth & vaniſheth away ſuddenly & irrecoverably. When the Goſpel was firſt publiſhed by Chriſt, and Thoſe ſent by him immediately to preach it, the Kingdom of darkneſs was ſoon weakned, and did apparently go to wreck. The Devil was beaten out of his Territories, his Temples were demoliſhed, his Altars thrown down, and his Oracles ſilenced. With that Rod of his Strength which Chriſt ſent out of Zion, he deſtroyed the Works of the Devil, 2 Cor. 10.4. The weapons of our warfare are not carnal, but mighty thro' God, to the pulling down of ſtrong Holds. The Apoſtles Warfare againſt Principalities and Powers was ſpiritual, the Weapons they uſed were not carnal, yet mighty thro' GOD: They atchieved glorious Conqueſts, but not by the edge of the Sword, or ſtratagems of War: The Goſpel was, thro' GOD the mighty and effectual Weapon, with which they batter'd the Devil's Fortreſſes, and over-turn'd his Dominion. The Goſpel prevail'd againſt the Learning of Philoſophers, and Power of Earthly Kings, and gloriouſly triumph'd over all the Oppoſition
which it met with from the Gates of Hell. Dagon fell before the Ark of GOD; and the Magicians Serpents were devoured by Aaron's Rod; ſo the Goſpel was too hard for all the Strength and Wiſdom of the World. The Walls of Jericho fell down at the Prieſts blowing of the Rams Horns; ſo when the Trumpet of the Goſpel was ſounded by the Miniſters thereof, down went the Images, Idolatries and Superſtitions of the Gentiles, and the Religion of Chriſt took place, and his Kingdom was ſet up on the Ruin of Satan's. In a few Years the Goſpel (like Leaven which ſoon leaveneth the whole Lump) ſpread into almoſt all parts of the known World. Col. 1.6. The Goſpel is come unto you, as it is in all the World. The great Change wrought in the World, by means of the Goſpel, at the firſt Preaching of it, ſpeaks it glorious.
2. THE Effects which the Goſpel ſtill produceth in the Souls of Men are great ana glorious.
IN regard of thoſe things eſpecially, which the Goſpel, accompanied with the holy Spirit, effecteth in the Souls of Believers, the Apoſtle doth in our Text and Context ſo magnify it above the Law.
1. THE Goſpel worketh effectually to the Converſion of Souls.

NOT only was Satan's viſible Kingdom in the World marvellouſly deſtroy'd by the Goſpel, at the firſt Preaching of it, but alſo his inviſible Empire in the Hearts of Sinners is continually broken by this Rod of Chriſt's ſtrength, which he hath ſent out of Zion. This daſheth in pieces the Works of the Devil within Men, as powerfully as it did thoſe without them. The ſtrong Holds which he hath erected in the Souls of Men, blindneſs of Mind, hardneſs of Heart, ſtubbornneſs of Will, and the like, are demoliſhed by the Goſpel, as gloriouſly as were the falſe Religions, Idolatries and Superſtitions, which he had ſet up in the World. Luke 11.21, 22. When a ſtrong man armed keepeth his palace, his goods are in peace. But when a ſtronger than he ſhall come upon him, and
overcome him, he taketh from him all his armour wherein he truſted, and divideth his ſpoil. Satan is the ſtrong Man armed, the Heart of every unconverted Sinner is his Garriſon which he keeps ſhut up, and barred again CHRIST, by unreaſonable Prejudices, carnal Inclinations and worldly Intereſts; but the King of Glory, by his Spirit in the Goſpel, comes upon, and caſts out the ſtrong Man armed, ſtorms and takes his Fort, and converteth it into a holy Temple. Upon the white Horſe of the pure Word of Truth, the mighty Redeemer ſtill rideth forth conquering, and to conquer, Rev. 6.2. By means of the Goſpel Perſons are turned from darkneſs to light, and from the power of Satan unto God. The Goſpel, and not the Law, is the Inſtrumental Cauſe of ſaving Converſion, Cont. ver. 8. The Letter killeth, but the Spirit giveth life. The moral Law revealing Man's Duty, and denouncing GOD'S Wrath againſt Him for not performing it, killeth: It makes Sin to revive in the Conſcience, and the guilty to dye. It only ſheweth Sinners that they are dead Men, being condemned already; and diſcovers to them no poſſible way of eſcaping the Curſe, and offers no Grace, no ſupernatural Strength unto them to enable them to get out of the State of Nature. But the Spirit giveth Life: The Goſpel which is called the Spirit quickeneth thoſe who are dead in Treſpaſſes and Sins. Spiritual Life is infuſed by means of the Goſpel: The holy Ghoſt uſeth it as his Inſtrument in quickning of dead Souls, Converting of ſinful Men, Joh. 5.25. Verily, verily I ſay unto you, the hour is coming, and now is, when the dead ſhall hear the voice of the Son of God; and they that hear ſhall live. CHRIST'S voice in the Goſpel raiſeth the ſpiritually dead. The beginning and progreſs of Converſion is by means of the Goſpel; the whole conformity of the Soul unto Chriſt is wrought thereby; as the Apoſtle ſheweth in our Context, Ver. 18. We all with open face, beholding as in a glaſs the glory of the Lord, are changed into the ſame Image; from glory to glory, even as by the Spirit of the Lord. The fight of the
LORD'S Glory in the Glaſs of the Goſpel, is tranſforming; Changeth the Soul into the Image and likeneſs of CHRIST. The Spirit of GOD worketh a ſaving Change in the Heart of a Sinner, by giving him a clear view of CHRIST'S Glory, as the Goſpel repreſents it. And the holy Ghoſt carries on the work of Sanctification in Believers, by enabling them to ſee more and more of the LORD'S Glory in that Glaſs: They are changed into his Image, from Glory to Glory; that is, from one degree of Grace to another, until they arrive to the perfection of Holineſs. All the Degrees of our conformity to CHRIST are ſtiled Glory; the firſt and loweſt degree of Grace is Glory begun, and the higheſt is Glory perfected. Believers ſee the Glory of the Lord in the Goſpel, and are changed into the ſame Image, from Glory to Glory; that is, (as one conceiveth from the alluſion to a Glaſs) "The Glory of the Lord ſhining upon the Goſpel, and from the Goſpel ſhining upon our Hearts, doth Change them into the Image of the ſame Glory; even as the Glory of the Sun ſhining upon a Glaſs, and from that Glaſs reflecting on a Wall, doth therein produce an Image of it's own light." Thus it is by the Goſpel that a ſaving Change is wrought in the Soul. This Glory is peculiar to the Goſpel. It is ſaid indeed, that the Law of the Lord is perfect, converting the Soul, Pſal. 19.7. But by the Law here, as in many other Texts of Scripture, is meant the whole Word of GOD, comprehending the Promiſes of Salvation by Chriſt. The moral Law is not the Inſtrumental Cauſe of Converſion. It prepares a Soul for Converſion, inaſmuch as by it is the knowledge of Sin: It convinceth the Sinner of Guilt, and deſerved Damnation, but leaves him ſhut up under the fearful Curſe, without the leaſt hope of eſcape. Did not the Goſpel reveal that God was in Chriſt reconciling the world unto himſelf, the awaken'd Sinner wou'd pine away in his Iniquities. It is not the Terror of the LORD, which 〈◊〉 in the Law, but his Glory ſhining in the Goſpel, that produceth a ſaving Change in the Heart.
2. PEACE of Conſcience is an excellent Effect of the Goſpel.

BY Peace of Conſcience, I mean that reſt and comfort which the believing Soul enjoyeth in the expectation and perſwaſion of GOD'S Mercy thro' CHRIST, to pardon and ſave it. This is the product of the Goſpel of Peace. The Law is in our Context ſtiled the miniſtration of Condemnation, becauſe it paſſeth the Sentence of Death upon the Tranſgreſſor of it, and gives Conſcience it's Authority to condemn the Sinner: But the Goſpel is called the miniſtration of Righteouſneſs, becauſe it exhibits and offers a Righteouſneſs ſufficient for our Juſtification: Therein is the Righteouſneſs of God revealed from faith to faith, Rom. 1.17. The Goſpel revealing that perfect Righteouſneſs, which GOD graciouſly imputeth without the Works of the Law, to thoſe who believe in Chriſt, is the means of ſetling an happy Peace in the Conſcience. Now, as the Apoſtle ſaith in the verſe immediately preceding our Text, If the miniſtration of Condemnation be glory, much more doth the miniſtration of Righteouſneſs exceed in Glory. The Goſpel far excels the Law in that it is the miniſtration of Righteouſneſs, and ſo of Peace. It is true, there is ſome mention made of this Righteouſneſs in the Writings of Moſes and the Prophets; hence it is ſaid, Rom. 3.21, 22. Now the Righteouſneſs of God without the Law is manifeſted, being witneſſed by the Law and the Prophets; even the Righteouſneſs of God which is by faith of Jeſus Chriſt, unto all, and upon all them that believe. But by the Law here the Apoſtle doth not intend the moral Law, for that is wholly ſilent concerning an imputed Righteouſneſs: But he means the Law of Commandments contained in Ordinances, the ceremonial Law; and it is certain, that the Sacrifices under the Law did typify the Death of CHRIST, by which we have now received the Atonement; and there were alſo many Propheſies and Promiſes of Chriſt, as the Lord our Righteouſneſs; and yet the glorious Myſtery of Juſtification by Faith in Chriſt, was in a great meaſure kept ſecret until the Goſpel manifeſted
it. In the Tabernacle were offered both gifts and ſacrifices, that could not make him that did the ſervice perfect, as pertaining to the conſcience, Heb. 9.9. They indeed prefigur'd a Sacrifice ſufficient to pacify Wrath, and quiet Conſcience, yet thoſe Sacrifices, and alſo the Promiſes and Propheſies which the Old Teſtament Church enjoyed, were but an obſcure exhibition of that Righteouſneſs which is the foundation of Pardon and Peace, Heb. 10.1. For the Law having a ſhadow of good things to come, and not the very image of the things, can never with thoſe ſacrifices, which they offered year by year continually, make the comers thereunto perfect. "The Jewiſh Ordinances were rather a Bond acknowledging the Debt, than an Acquittance ſhewing the Diſcharge; therefore called, The Hand-writing of Ordinances againſt us." But the Goſpel clearly revealing the Righteouſneſs of CHRIST for our Juſtification, maketh thoſe who receive it perfect as pertaining to the Conſcience.
3. A glorious Liberty is another Effect of the Goſpel.

THE glorious Liberty of the Children of GOD is ſpoken of, Rom. 8.21. It is by the Goſpel that Men are made Partakers of it. Where the Spirit of the Lord is, there is Liberty, Cont. v. 17. By the Liberty of the Children of GOD, we may underſtand ſuch an ingenuous Diſpoſition as that Men do look upon, and act towards GOD as a gracious Father, in and thro' JESUS CHRIST. The Law, the Covenant from Mount Sinai gendreth to Bondage, Gal. 4.24. Thoſe who are under it, are in the Condition of Slaves, not of Sons. It produceth ſuch a Temper and Spirit towards GOD, as Slaves uſually have toward their Maſters; being influenced to their Duty only by Fear, or an apprehenſion of the Severity of their Maſters, and the ſmart of the Rod. But the Goſpel produceth a Child-like Temper in the Souls of Believers. By it they receive, not the Spirit of bondage again to fear, but the ſpirit of adoption, whereby they cry, Abba, Father, Rom. 8.15. It gives a filial Freedom, ſo that Believers may come unto GOD
at all times, as Children to a Father: They may come to the Throne of Grace, in every time of need, with greater boldneſs, than the High-Prieſt under the Law could once a Year enter into the Holieſt of all.
THUS the Goſpel in regard of the Effects produced by it, is more glorious than the Law.
VII. THE Goſpel is far more glorious than the Law in reſpect of the Duration of it.

THERE is verily a diſannulling of the commandment going before, for the weakneſs and unprofitableneſs thereof, Heb. 7.18. An end is put to the Legal Diſpenſation, but the Evangelical ſhall continue to the End of the World, Matth. 28.19, 20. Go ye therefore and teach all nations, baptizing them in the name, of the Father, and of the Son, and of the holy Ghoſt: Teaching them to obſerve all things whatſoever I have commanded you: and lo, I am with you alway, even unto the End of the World. Had there been no defect in the Legal, GOD would not have introduc'd the Evangelical Diſpenſation: The Change is to the better: GOD will not alter or abrogate the preſent Diſpenſation, becauſe there is not a better to ſucceed in the room of it, Heb. 12.26, 27. Whoſe voice then ſhook the Earth, but now he hath promiſed, ſaying, yet once more I ſhake not the Earth only, but alſo Heaven. And this word, yet once more, ſignifieth the removing of thoſe things that are ſhaken, as of things that are made, that thoſe things which cannot be ſhaken may remain. The LORD'S voice ſhook the Earth, when he deliver'd the Law at Sinai; the whole Mount quaked greatly: but he ſhook not the Earth only, but alſo Heaven, the Jewiſh Church-State, at the bringing in of the Goſpel. And he removed the Types and Ordinances of the Law, as things never deſigned by him the Appointer and Founder of them, to continue always; and ſo made way for the Introduction & Eſtabliſhment of the Goſpel and the Ordinances thereof, which are things that cannot be ſhaken, but ſhall remain to the End of the
World. The Goſpel-ſtate is that Kingdom which cannot be moved. The Angel which John ſaw flying in the midſt of Heaven, (which might denote the ſpeed and diligence of Chriſt's faithful Ambaſſadors) had the everlaſting Goſpel to preach unto them that dwell on the Earth, Rev. 14.6. This proves the tranſcendent Excellency of the Goſpel. For (as the Apoſtle ſaith in the verſe following our Text) if that which was done away was glorious, much more that which remaineth is glorious.
IN theſe reſpects the Goſpel exceedeth the Law in Glory, and ſo far that even that which was made glorious, had no Glory, in compariſon of the Glory that excelleth.
HAVING thus Illuſtrated and Confirmed the Truth, I proceed to Apply it.
1. IS the Goſpel ſo much more glorious than the Law? We may hence infer the great Dignity of the Evangelical Miniſtry.

IT is conſiſtent with the Humility that ſhou'd cloath the Miniſters of the lowly JESUS, to aſſert the Dignity of their ſacred Employment. The holy Apoſtle Paul, who counted himſelf leſs than the leaſt of all Saints, is, in the Chapter wherein our Text is, magnifying his Office; and he ſtrongly proves it honourable from the tranſcendent Glory of the Goſpel. His genuine Inference from his large Diſcourſe concerning the Excellency of the Goſpel is that in Ver. 12, 13. Cont. Seeing then that we have ſuch hope, we uſe great plainneſs of ſpeech, and not as Moſes, who put a vail over his face. As if he had ſaid, The Goſpel being in ſo many reſpects more glorious than the Law, and eſpecially ſince, according to our certain Expectation, it ſhall continue to the End of the World, I am not aſhamed of my miniſtration, but do thus boldly vindicate my Apoſtleſhip, and do not, as Moſes vail the Glory which the LORD hath put upon me. The more excellent a divine Revelation is, the more noble
is their Office, who are ſent with it to the Children of Men. It was glorious to be a Miniſter of the Law, it is much more ſo to be a Miniſter of the Goſpel. John the Baptiſt, CHRIST'S Harbinger and Herald, was more than a Miniſter of the Law, more than a Prophet: The Law and the Prophets were until John: But in his Time Chriſt was actually exhibited, and he declar'd the Meſſiah to be already come, pointing him out, as it were with the Finger, ſaying, Behold the Lamb of GOD. So that John's Miniſtry excel'd any that was before; yet when our Saviour was ſpeaking of John's greatneſs, he ſhow'd that under the Evangelical Diſpenſation, when the Goſpel ſhou'd be fully preached, the leaſt Miniſter thereof wou'd, in reſpect of his Office, be greater than John, be a more honourable Officer than he, Matth. 11.11. Verily I ſay unto you, among them that are born of women, there hath not riſen a greater than John the Baptiſt: notwithſtanding, he that is leaſt in the Kingdom of Heaven, is greater than he. The more glorious a Kingdom is, the more honourable is an Office in it: The Goſpel Kingdom is termed the Kingdom of Heaven; the Glory of it exceeds that of all the Kingdoms of this World: To be a Miniſter therefore of CHRIST'S ſpiritual Kingdom on Earth, is no mean Preferment. No Man taketh this Honour unto himſelf, without horrid Uſurpation, but he that is called of GOD to this high and holy Office, ſhou'd be very humble and thankful; ſaying with the great Apoſtle Paul, Eph. 3.8. Unto me, who am leſs than the leaſt of all Saints, is this Grace given, that I ſhould preach among the Gentiles the unſearchable Riches of Chriſt: And, 1 Tim. 1.12. I thank Chriſt Jeſus our Lord who hath enabled me, for that he counted me faithful, putting me into the Miniſtry.— And they unto whoſe Truſt the glorious Goſpel of the bleſſed GOD is committed, ſhould be careful to ſupport the Dignity of their Office, which they can do in no ſuch effectual way, as by diſcharging faithfully the Duties belonging to it— And let every Man ſo account of them, as the Miniſters of Chriſt,
and Stewards of the myſteries of God: and this is to count them worthy of double honour, and to eſteem them very highly in Love for their work's ſake. That is ſpoken of, and in the New-Teſtament is directly apply'd to the Miniſters of the glorious Goſpel, which we read in Iſa. 52.7. How beautiful upon the mountains are the feet of him that bringeth good tidings, that publiſheth peace, that bringeth good tidings of good, that publiſheth ſalvation, that ſaith unto Zion, thy God reigneth.
2. DOTH the Goſpel exceed the Law in Glory? then the Sin of Deſpiſing it is very great.

NOTWITHSTANDING the Goſpel is ſo incomparably glorious, yet there are multitudes that deſpiſe it. When it was firſt publiſhed to the World, the generality of Men look'd upon it as a very mean or ridiculous Doctrine, and not worthy to be regarded by Rational Beings: They called the Preaching of it fooliſhneſs. And the moſt of Men do not entertain a better Opinion of it, at this Day: Some deſpiſe it ſo as to reject the Knowledge of it; they have no deſire and take no pains to underſtand the glorious Truths contained in it. Some are aſhamed of the Goſpel of CHRIST, aſham'd to profeſs it; and how light do Sinners commonly make of the Overtures of Grace therein? All who believe not in CHRIST, and walk not according to the Rules of the Goſpel, are guilty of deſpiſing it. He that breaks the Law deſpiſeth it, 2 Sam. 12.9. Wherefore haſt thou deſpiſed the Commandment of the Lord, to do evil in his ſight? So all who diſobey the Goſpel deſpiſe it; and the greatneſs of their Sin and Folly appears from the Glory of the Goſpel. The more excellent any thing is, the more vile is the Contempt of it. As much as the Goſpel exceeds the Law in Glory, ſo much worſe is it for Men to deſpiſe the Goſpel than the Law, and expoſeth them to ſo much heavier Puniſhments. Heb. 10.28, 29. He that deſpiſed Moſes Law, died without mercy, under two or three witneſſes: of how much ſorer puniſhment, ſuppoſe ye, ſhall he be thought worthy, who hath
trodden under foot the Son of God, and hath counted the blood of the Covenant wherewith he was ſanctified, and unholy thing, and hath done deſpite unto the Spirit of Grace? Contempt of the Goſpel is treading the Son of GOD underfoot, as if he were really a Worm and no Man, much leſs GOD: It is ſetting of him at nought, as truly as Herod with his Men of War did, when they made a mock-King of him: It is trampling the Redeemer's Grace, as if it were nothing worth: And it is counting his precious Blood, which is the Blood of the Covenant, an unholy, a common thing; ſuch as pollutes rather than purifies the Soul. Deſpiſing the Goſpel is doing Deſpite unto the Spirit of Grace, the holy Ghoſt, which accompanies the Goſpel to perſwade Men of the Truth and Excellency of it, and to make it of ſaving Efficacy to them. So great is the Sin of Goſpel-Contempt that Chriſt ſaid concerning thoſe who were guilty of deſpiſing the Law and the Prophets, Joh. 16.22 — 24. If I had not come, and ſpoken unto them, they had not had Sin: but now they have no cloke for their Sin — If I had not done among them the works which none other man did, they had not had Sin: but now they have both ſeen, and hated both me and my father. The righteous GOD puniſheth this Sin with the greateſt Judgments, temporal, ſpiritual and eternal. Wrath came not upon the Jews to the uttermoſt, until they deſpiſed and perſecuted the Goſpel, Mat. 22.7. When the King heard thereof, he was wroth: and he ſent forth his Armies, (the Romans) and deſtroyed thoſe murderers, and burnt up their City. The ſoreſt outward Calamities are brought on a People, who enjoy the Goſpel, for their Contempt of it. GOD is provoked by Men's deſpiſing the Goſpel, to ſmite them with Judicial Blindneſs, ſo that they never ſhall ſee the Glory of it, Joh. 12.40, 41. They who contemptuouſly ſhut their Eyes againſt the light of the Goſpel, GOD often Judicially cloſeth their Eyes, and delivers them to the Power of Satan to blind them, 2 Cor. 4.3, 4. If our Goſpel be hid, it is hid to them
that are loſt: In whom the God of this world hath blinded the eyes of thoſe that believe not, leſt the light of the glorious Goſpel of Chriſt, who is the Image of God, ſhould ſhine unto them. The Deſpiſers of the Goſpel ſhall be puniſhed with everlaſting Deſtruction: And it will be more tolerable, not only for Sodom and Gomorrah, but alſo for the Deſpiſers of Moſes Law in the Day of Judgment, than for them, 2 Theſ. 1.7, 8. The Lord Jeſus ſhall be revealed from Heaven, with his mighty Angels, in flaming fire, taking vengeance on them that know not God, and that obey not the Goſpel of our Lord Jeſus Chriſt. — Now conſider this, ye that contemn the glorious Goſpel, and beware leſt that come upon you which is ſpoken of in the Prophets: Behold, ye deſpiſers, and wonder, and periſh.
3. LET what hath been ſaid, raiſe our Eſteem of the Goſpel.

THAT which is glorious ought to be valu'd by us, and according to the degree of it's Excellence. The Diſplay of the tranſcendent Glory of the Goſpel ſhou'd excite and confirm in us a due Eſteem of it. — What hath been ſaid concerning the Glory of the Goſpel, diſparageth not the Law, and will not juſtify the Contempt of it. The Law is glorious, and deſerveth eſteem. It was a moſt ſuitable Revelation for the People to whom, and the Time wherein it was granted. Infinite Wiſdom judg'd it fit that the diſcovery of GOD'S Mind & Will concerning the Salvation of fallen Man, ſhou'd be like the dawning Light, which ſhineth more and more unto the perfect day. A meridian Brightneſs was not proper for the Morning of the Church Times. Under the Law the Church was, as it were, in her non-age; and the Inſtructions GOD gave were ſuited to her Capacity. Believers were then Children, and the Law was their School-maſter, to teach them the Elements, the Rudiments, the firſt Principles of divine Knowledge: Gal. 3.24. The Law was our School-maſter to bring us unto Chriſt: It was to prepare the Church for the Univerſity of the Goſpel,
in which the Knowledge of Chriſt is more fully taught. GOD vouchſafed further light to his People by extraordinary Prophets which he ſent unto them: He at ſundry Times, and in diverſe manners, ſpake unto the Fathers by the Prophets, who predicted what the Law prefigur'd, and gave many Promiſes of the Meſſiah. Yet it was not perfect day-light until the Sun of Righteouſneſs aroſe; then the ſhadows fled away, "and the whole Horizon of heavenly Truth was diſclos'd." So that altho' the Law was glorious the divine Revelation before the fulneſs of Time came was excellent, and to be greatly eſteemed, yet the Goſpel is far more glorious, and to be more highly valued. The Inſtructions of the Law were beggarly Elements, mean Rudiments, in compariſon of the deeper and more full Inſtructions of the Goſpel. That is a notable Prophecy concerning the Evangelical Diſpenſation, Jer. 3.14, 15, 16. I will take you one of a city, and two of a family, and I will bring you to Zion. And I will give you Paſtors according to mine heart, which ſhall feed you with knowledge & underſtanding. And it ſhall come to paſs when ye be multiplied and increaſed in the Land; In thoſe days, ſaith the Lord, they ſhall ſay no more, The Ark of the Covenant of the Lord: neither ſhall it come to mind, neither ſhall they remember it, neither ſhall they viſit it, neither ſhall that be done any more. The days of the Meſſiah are here intended, in which GOD'S People ſhould be fed with Wiſdom and Underſtanding, by faithful evangelical Paſtors, in a way different from the Jewiſh Inſtitution. And their prizing the Goſpel Diſpenſation above the former, is expreſs'd by their not remembring, mentioning, nor viſiting the Ark of the Covenant. The Ark was called, The Glory; it was very much the Glory of Iſrael: It was an eminent Type of Chriſt, (the Glory of his People;) and a Symbol of GOD'S Preſence with his ancient Church. The Old-Teſtament Saints had it in high account; nothing was more precious unto them: yet it is here foretold, that when Chriſt, the Antitype of the
Ark, ſhould he come, and a more ſpiritual Worſhip erected, then there ſhould be no mention made of the Ark, it ſhould not be remembred, nor come into mind, neither ſhall that be done any more in it, or, as the Margin renders this, It ſhall not be magnified any more, It ſhall not be had in honour or reſpect, or be made much of. The whole ceremonial Law is not to be valued in compariſon of the glorious Goſpel; nor the carnal Ordinances of the former, to be mentioned in the ſame day with the ſpiritual Ordinances of the latter. The moral Law is to be highly eſteem'd. GOD will magnify this Law, and make it honourable. It is truly excellent and honourable in it ſelf; and the things of it are great things, and ſhou'd be ſo in our account. But the moral Law is only a Revelation of GOD'S Will concerning Man's Duty, not of his Good-Will concerning Man's Salvation. It ſheweth us what we ought to do, and condemns us for not doing it, and leaves us without hope of eſcaping it's dreadful Curſe. It is a perfect Rule of Obedience, but affords no ſtrength unto impotent Man to walk according to it. Now the Goſpel doth not make void the Law, as it is a perfect Rule of Life and Manners, but re-inforceth it, and farther ſhews how the Sinner may be freed from the Curſe, revealing a Righteouſneſs that anſwers the Demands of the Law, and offers Strength to enable us ſincerely & acceptably to keep the divine Precepts. All the intrinſic Glory which the moral Law hath, the Goſpel hath, and much more: We ſhould therefore give the Goſpel the preference to the Law in our eſteem. GOD'S Law was more deſired by his Saints than Gold, yea than much fine Gold, It was better to them than Thouſands of Gold & Silver. How then ought we to prize the glorious Goſpel? It is an ineſtirnable Pearl we ſhou'd be willing to part with all things rather than to be without it, Matth. 13.4 • , 46. The Kingdom of Heaven is like unto a merchant-man, ſeeking goodly Pearls: who when he had found one Pearl of great price, he went and ſold all that he had, and bought it. How
were the ancient Promiſes valued by thoſe who looked for Redemption? Heb. 11.1 •
Theſe all died in Faith, not having received 〈◊〉 Promiſes (i. e. The Accompliſhment of them in the actual Exhibition of the Meſſiah) but having ſeen them afar off, and were perſwaded of them, and imbraced them. As good old Simeon took up CHRIST in his Arms, ſo the Patriarchs by Faith imbraced the Promiſes, "ſaluted and hugged them," as the original word imports. When they meditated on the Promiſes, did they not cry out, Oh dear precious Promiſes that will in time yield the Meſſiah! How then ought we to value the Goſpel, which is the completion of thoſe Promiſes? Shall we not embrace the glorious Goſpel: count it worthy of all acceptation? worthy to be receiv'd with all readineſs of Mind, and ſtrength of Affection.
4. LET us all be ſolicitous that the Goſpel may produce it's glorious Effects in our Souls.

WE have ſeen that the Goſpel is far more glorious than the Law in regard of thoſe wonderful Effects produced by it in the Souls of Men: We ſhould be anxiouſly concern'd that this Glory of the Goſpel be manifeſted and magnified in our Converſion & Salvation. There muſt indeed be firſt a Work of the Law on our Hearts, convincing us of Sin and Wrath, to prepare us for a Work of the Goſpel, in Changing our Hearts, and encouraging us to believe in Chriſt We muſt ſeek, that the Commandment may come with power on our Souls, to revive the ſenſe of our Guilt and Miſery, and to ſlay us; to make us ſee that we are condemned Malefactors, dead in Treſpaſſes and Sins: and then that the Goſpel may come unto us in Power, & in the holy Ghoſt, to give us life. We muſt look for a ſaving Change to be wro't in us by the Goſpel, as a fit Inſtrument in the Hand of GOD'S Spirit. The moral Law was never deſign'd for this uſe. If ever we be ſpiritually begotten, it muſt be thro' the Goſpel. The Children of Promiſe the Heirs
of Salvation are not born of the Bond-woman, Gal. 4.22, &c. All the Terrors on Mount Sinai will not drive a Sinner out of his natural Eſtate, home unto Chriſt. There muſt be a Hope ſet before him, or he will not fly for Refuge. It is not the ſight of GOD'S Glory in the Glaſs of the Law, but of the Goſpel that is transforming. The Glory on the Face of Moſes, which was ſuch that the Iſraelites could not ſtedfaſtly behold him, is not ſufficient; there muſt be a diſcovery of the Glory of GOD in the Face of JESUS CHRIST, in order to a ſaving Illumination. The Glory of divine Mercy & Wiſdom in our Redemption by CHRIST, muſt be ſeen by him that believes in CHRIST, and is transformed into his Image. Let us therefore give earneſt heed to the Goſpel, as the Inſtituted ordinary Means of thorow Converſion. Let it be our great Care, vehement Deſire and conſtant Prayer, that the Goſpel may work effectually in us, as it doth in all them that believe—May be the Power of God unto our Salvation. How ſad is it, if we who now ſpeak, and hear ſo much of the Glory of the Goſpel, experience nothing of it's Power on our Hearts, changing of them, and carrying on a Work of Grace in them! How dreadful is it, to have the glorious Goſpel prove a ſavour of Death unto Death! Let us pray that it may come to us, not in Word only, (for then it will eventually be a killing Letter, as well as the Law) but alſo in power, and in the holy Ghoſt; that ſo it's Glory may be exemplify'd and diſplay'd in our Salvation.
5. FROM what has been ſaid, Let us be incited to a more diligent Study of the Goſpel.

THE Glory of GOD is more fully and clearly reveal'd in the Goſpel, than it is in the Law: But we cannot ſee it, nor be affected with it, unleſs we apply our Minds to the ſtudy of the Goſpel. The Myſteries of the Goſpel afford the moſt delightful Entertainment to inquiſitive Minds. The ancient Prophets, who foretold ſomething of the Glory of the Goſpel, us'd
to ſtudy their own Prophecies concerning it, 1 Pet. 1.10, 11, 12. Of which Salvation the Prophets have enquired, and ſearched diligently, who propheſied of the Grace that ſhould come unto you: ſearching what, or what manner of time the Spirit of Chriſt which was in them did ſignify, when it teſtified beforehand the ſufferings of Chriſt, and the Glory that ſhould follow: Unto whom it was revealed, that not unto themſelves, but unto us they did miniſter the things which are now reported unto you by them that have preached the Goſpel, with the holy Ghoſt coming down from Heaven, which things the Angels deſire to look into. The holy Prophets with great diligence and delight ſearched into thoſe unfathomable Myſteries of Grace, that were in dark Expreſſions ſpoken of by themſelves, as moved by the Spirit of GOD, and which are more fully and clearly declared in the Goſpel: Which Things (ſaith the Apoſtle) the Angels deſire to look into. This Expreſſion is alluſive to the Cherubims which were over the Ark, a Type of Chriſt, looking down earneſtly upon it, as if they would pry into it. The bleſſed Angels, who behold the Face of GOD in Heaven, do as it were turn their Eyes from viewing his Glory in the upper World, and bend down their ſacred Heads to look into the glorious Myſteries of the Goſpel. The manifold Wiſdom of GOD made known to the Principalities and Powers in heavenly Places, by the Diſpenſation of his Grace toward the Church, is wonderful and raviſhing to them. And ſhall not we ſtudy thoſe things, which the glorious Angels think ſo worthy their Contemplations? Let us faithfully improve all Means, that are proper and appointed for our Information in the great and important Truths of the Goſpel. Let us, with the very learned Apoſtle Paul, Count all things but loſs for the Excellency of the Knowledge of Chriſt Jeſus, our Lord. — And as David prayed unto GOD, ſaying, Open thou mine Eyes, that I may behold wondrous things out of thy Law; ſo let us pray that GOD
would open our Eyes, that we may behold more wondrous things out of his Goſpel.
6. LET Chriſtians be Exhorted to adorn the glorious Goſpel, the Doctrine of God our Saviour in all things.

WE cannot add to the intrinſick Glory of the Goſpel, but we ſhould teſtify and declare it's Excellency by having our Converſation in the World as becometh the Goſpel of Chriſt. It is a Reproach to the glorious Goſpel, and brings it into Contempt, when thoſe who profeſs it walk not according to the holy and excellent Rules of it, Rom. 2.23, 24. Thou that makeſt thy boaſt of the Law, thro' breaking the Law diſhonoureſt thou God? For the name of God is blaſphemed among the Gentiles thro' you. So when Profeſſors of Chriſtianity diſobey the Precepts of it, they darken the Glory of the Goſpel, and diſhonour the Name of Chriſt. We receive the Grace of GOD the Goſpel in vain, as to our own Souls, unleſs we conform our Lives to it: as it is ſhown they had as good have been without the Law, who did not keep it, Jer. 8.8. How do ye ſay, we are wiſe, and the Law of the Lord is with us? Lo, certainly in vain made he it, the Pen of the Scribes is in vain. And we render the Goſpel unprofitable to others alſo by our unſuitable Lives: We increaſe and confirm their Prejudices, which hinder their ſeeing the Glory of the Goſpel.— But the Luſtre of a godly Converſation is an Ornament to the glorious Goſpel, which we profeſs. The regular Practice of all the duties which the Goſpel requires, ſets forth the Glory of the Goſpel to beſt Advantage, and recommends it to thoſe, before whom our Light ſhineth, and may convince even Infidels that the Goſpel came from the GOD of Glory. Chriſtians of the loweſt Rank are obliged thus to adorn the Goſpel, Tit. 2.9, 10 Let our Converſation therefore be as it becometh the Goſpel of Chriſt, Phil. 1.27. 1 Theſ. 2.11, 12. As ye know how we exhorted, and comforted, and
charged every one of you, as a father doth his children; That ye would walk worthy of God, who hath called you unto his Kingdom & Glory.
7. LET us be very Thankful to GOD for the Goſpel.

WHAT hath been ſaid concerning the Glory of the Goſpel (tho' one half hath not been told) may well excite our thankful Praiſes unto GOD for it. What Advantage had the Jews above the Gentiles? Much every way, chiefly becauſe that unto them were committed the Oracles of God. And Chriſtians have a vaſt advantage above the Jews, in that the glorious Goſpel of the Bleſſed GOD is committed unto them. GOD hath provided ſome better thing for us, that they without us ſhould not be made perfect. The Goſpel is a greater Glory unto a People, among whom it is diſpenſed in the Power & Purity of it, than the Ark was to Iſrael; and more Glory is due therefor unto GOD from thoſe who enjoy it. How glad would the Patriarchs and Prophets of old have been, to have ſeen and heard what we do under the Evangelical Diſpenſation? Matth. 13.16, 17. But bleſſed are your Eyes, for they ſee; and your Ears, for they hear: for verily I ſay unto you, that many Prophets and righteous Men have deſired to ſee thoſe things which ye ſee, and have not ſeen them: and to hear thoſe things, which ye hear; and have not heard them. They indeed by the Perſpective of Faith ſaw the promiſed Bleſſings; but they ſaw them afar off, had but an obſcure View of them to what is now granted. With the Eagle-Eye of Faith Abraham ſaw the Day of Goſpel-light at a great diſtance, and the remote Proſpect which he had of it, made him to rejoice greatly, Joh. 8.56. Your Father Abraham rejoyced to ſee my day: and he ſaw it, and was glad. Should not thoſe who live in that day, much more rejoyce in, and be thankful for the Light and Glory of it? GOD'S 〈…〉 People devoutly praiſed him for his diſtinguiſh 〈◊〉
•• vour
to them, in giving them the Law, Pſal. 147.19, 20. He ſheweth his word unto Jacob, his ſtatutes and his judgments unto Iſrael. He hath not dealt ſo with any nation: And as for his judgments they have not known them. Praiſe ye the Lord. Should not we much more praiſe him for ſending the glorious Goſpel unto us, when ſo many Nations in the World are as yet deſtitute of it? Luke 10.21. In that hour Jeſus rejoyced in ſpirit, and ſaid, I thank thee, O Father, Lord of Heaven and Earth, that thou haſt hid theſe things from the wiſe and prudent, and haſt revealed them unto babes: even ſo, Father, for ſo it ſeemed good in thy ſight.
